{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Use British English|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox company |name = University of Warwick Science Park |logo = UWSP Logo-2.jpg |logo_size = 200px |type = Private ([[Private company limited by shares|Limited liability]]) |foundation = 1984 |location_city = [[Coventry]] |location_country = United Kingdom |key_people = Professor [[Nigel Thrift]], [[Chairman]]
[[David Grindrod]], Acting Director |industry = [[Science, technology and society|Science and technology]] |products = [[Property]]
[[Business incubator|Incubation]]
Technical [[Marketing]]
[[Business Angel]] Network
[[Innovation]] [[Consultancy]] |num_employees = 25 |homepage = [http://www.uwsp.co.uk www.uwsp.co.uk] }} The '''University of Warwick Science Park''' (also known as '''UWSP''' and '''Warwick Science Park''') was one of the first university based science parks in the United Kingdom when it was opened by the Rt. Hon. [[Margaret Thatcher]] in 1984."[http://www.insidermedia.com/insider/midlands/4889-cover-story-rowes-rollercoaster/]." ''Insider Media''. Retrieved on 13 July 2011. "Rowe's Rollercoaster" It was a joint venture between the [[University of Warwick]], [[Coventry City Council]], [[Warwickshire County Council]] and [[Barclays]]. The latter are no longer shareholders having been replaced by WM Enterprise. The University of Warwick agreed in 2011 to purchase the shareholding of Coventry City Council."[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-coventry-warwickshire-12690034]." ''BBC News''. Retrieved on 13 July 2011. "Plans to Sell off Warwick Science Park" The acquisition was completed in 2012 and today the Science Park is wholly owned by the University of Warwick. UWSP currently covers four sites; the main campus abutting the [[University of Warwick]], the Business Innovation Centre in [[Binley, Coventry|Binley]], Warwick Innovation Centre on [[Warwick Technology Park]] and Blythe Valley Innovation Centre near [[Solihull]]. UWSP typically provides office and lab space for 145 businesses employing more than 1800 people. ==History== The University of Warwick Science Park was established in 1984 by the then [[Vice Chancellor]] of the University of Warwick, [[Lord Butterworth]]."[http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/about/history/]." ''University of Warwick''. Retrieved on 13 July 2011. "History" The first building, the Barclay's Venture Centre (now the Venture Centre) was formally opened by [[UK]] Prime Minister the Rt. Hon. Margaret Thatcher on 24 February 1984. In 2004, UWSP was awarded the 'Incubator of the Year' award by [[UKBI]]."[http://icbirmingham.icnetwork.co.uk/0150business/0200news/tm_objectid=14906647&method=full&siteid=50002&headline=science-park-is-best-in-country-name_page.html]".''IC Birmingham'' Retrieved on 13 July 2011. "Science Park is Best in Country" The founding Director of UWSP, [[David Rowe (executive)|David Rowe]], was awarded the [[Queen's Award for Enterprise Promotion]] in 2006."[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/the-queens-awards-number-of-winners-in-awards-for-industry-hits-11year-high-475009.html]." ''The Independent'' Retrieved on 13 July 2011. "The Queen's Award" In 2012 the University of Warwick acquired sole ownership of the Science Park. ==Facilities== ===University of Warwick === The University of Warwick Science Park’s main 42-acre campus is centred on the Venture Centre. It includes a further twenty buildings, some of which are owner occupied whilst others are leased. Many of the buildings on UWSP's campus are named after old British car models. The main buildings include:
The Venture Centre
Herald Court
Sovereign Court
Riley Court
Vanguard Centre
Viscount Centres ===Warwick Innovation Centre=== Warwick Innovation Centre opened at Warwick Technology Park in 1997 as a joint venture between UWSP and Warwickshire County Council. Further developments followed in 1999 & 2001 providing {{convert|45000|sqft|m2|-2|abbr=on}} of lettable space. ===Business Innovation Centre=== The {{convert|34000|sqft|m2|-2|abbr=on}} Business Innovation Centre at Binley, Coventry opened in April 2000 as a joint venture between UWSP and Coventry City Council. ===Blythe Valley Innovation Centre=== UWSP manages the {{convert|30000|sqft|m2|-3|abbr=on}} Innovation Centre at Blythe Valley Business Park on behalf of [[Solihull Metropolitan Borough Council]], [[Prologis]] and [[British Land]]. ==Activities== In addition to property services, UWSP offers a range of business support activities targeted at innovation led [[Small and medium enterprises|SME]]s. ===Investment Readiness=== Connect Midlands is a not-for-profit network, that supports technology and high growth companies to gain investment through training and mentoring, investment showcasing, and networking between businesses, investors and the professional services community in the Midlands. Since 2001 Connect Midlands has assisted hundreds of companies who have gone on to raise over £200 million in investment. ===Access to Finance (Minerva)=== UWSP hosts and manages the [[Business Angel]] Network, Minerva. MiNErVA is actually an acronym for Midlands Network of Entrepreneurs, Venturers and Angels. In addition to supporting a community of high-net-worth individuals, Minerva undertakes investment readiness consultancy and raises finance from [[bank]]s and [[venture capital]] funds. UWSP has also managed a number of seed investment funds including the fully invested UWSP Concepts Fund and the £7m Advantage Proof of Concept Fund. ===Technical Marketing (Techmark)=== Techmark has provided marketing services to established, start-up and pre-start technology businesses since 1996. Services include market exploration, market development, strategic planning, marketing execution and overseas market access. ===Incubation (Ignite)=== Ignite provides mentoring and subsidised incubator space for start-up, knowledge led firms. This is spread across three sites, the main campus, Warwick Innovation Centre and the Business Innovation Centre. ===Incubation (Labstart)=== Labstart provides subsidised offices and laboratory space for start-up technology businesses on UWSP's main campus. ===Incubation (UK Market Access Centre)=== The UK Market Access Centre provides a blend of subsidised office space and professional service support for foreign owned companies seeking to establish UK trading arms. Warwick Science Park is one of the founding members of the UK Market Access Program. ==See also== *[[List of science parks in the United Kingdom]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{University of Warwick}} {{DEFAULTSORT:University Of Warwick Science Park}} [[Category:High-technology business districts in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Science parks in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:University of Warwick|Science Park]]

[[File:Wartime civilian receiver.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Wartime civilian receiver, 1944-1945]] The '''Utility Radio''' or '''Wartime Civilian Receiver''' was a [[vacuum tube|valve]] domestic [[Superheterodyne receiver|radio receiver]], manufactured in [[United Kingdom|Great Britain]] during [[World War II]] starting in July 1944. It was designed by G.D Reynolds of [[Murphy Radio]]. Both AC and battery-operated versions were made.<ref name="Miller2000">{{cite book|last=Miller|first=Charles Edward|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=_DJZf2P0gFoC&source=gbs_navlinks_s|title=Valve Radio and Audio Repair Handbook|publisher=Newnes|year=2000|isbn=0-7506-3995-4|pp= 144-151}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vintage-radio.com/manufacturers-and-sets/wartime.html |title=Wartime manufactuerers and sets |publisher=vintageradio.com |accessdate=2014-12-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303233134/http://www.vintage-radio.com/manufacturers-and-sets/wartime.html |archivedate=2016-03-03 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Street2002" />
==History== When war broke out in 1939, British radio manufacturers devoted their resources to producing a range of military radio equipment required for the armed forces. This resulted in a shortage of consumer radio sets and spare parts, particularly valves, as all production was for the services. The war also prompted a shortage of radio repairmen, as virtually all of them were needed in the services to maintain vital radio and radar equipment. This meant it was very difficult for the average citizen to get a radio repaired, and with very few new sets available, there was a desperate need to overcome the problem.<ref name="ClassicWireless" />
The Government solved this by arranging for over 40 radio manufacturers to produce sets to a standard design with as few components as possible consistent with ability to source them. Earlier the Government had introduced the [[Utility clothing|'Utility']] brand to ensure that all clothing, which was rationed, was produced to a reasonable quality standard as prior to its introduction a lot of shoddy goods had appeared on the market. So the 'Utility' brand was adopted for this wartime radio.<ref name="Street2002">{{cite book|author=Sean Street|title=A Concise History of British Radio, 1922-2002|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y7jo0IcUZeoC&pg=PA78|year=2002|publisher=Kelly Publications|isbn=978-1-903053-14-0|p=78}}</ref><ref name="Miller2000"/>
The Utility Set had limited reception on [[medium wave]] and lacked a [[longwave]] band to simplify the design. The tuning scale listed only BBC stations. After the war a version with LW was made available and modification kits to retrofit existing sets were marketed.<ref name="valve">{{cite web|url=http://www.thevalvepage.com/radios/wartime/mains/warmains.htm |title=Wartime mains |publisher=Thevalvepage.com |accessdate=2006-03-04 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303192706/http://www.thevalvepage.com/radios/wartime/mains/warmains.htm |archivedate=2016-03-03 |df= }}</ref>
About 175,000 sets were sold, at a price of £12 3s 4d each.<ref name="ClassicWireless">{{cite web|url=http://www.classicwireless.btinternet.co.uk/warciva.htm|title=Wartime Civilian Receiver|publisher=ClassicWireless.co.uk|year=2003|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011231913/http://www.classicwireless.btinternet.co.uk/warciva.htm|archivedate=2012-10-11|accessdate=2017-01-11}}</ref> The set is sometimes characterized as the British equivalent of the German [[Volksempfänger]] "Peoples' Receiver"; however there were dissimilarities. The ''Volksempfänger'' were radio sets designed to be inexpensive enough for any German citizen to purchase one. A supply of higher quality consumer radios were always available to Germans who could afford to pay higher prices. By contrast, the Utility Set was the only consumer radio receiver that could be purchased on the British market for much of the latter part of the war.<ref name="Ross2010">{{cite book|author=Corey Ross|title=Media and the Making of Modern Germany: Mass Communications, Society, and Politics from the Empire to the Third Reich|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RxytXTsadScC&pg=PA1805|date=6 May 2010|publisher=OUP Oxford|isbn=978-0-19-161494-1|pages=1805–}}</ref> Starting in June 1942, manufacture of consumer radio receivers in the [[United States]] also ceased due to military production needs.<ref name="McGregorDriscoll2016">{{cite book|author1=Michael A. McGregor|author2=Paul D. Driscoll|author3=Walter Mcdowell|title=Head's Broadcasting in America: A Survey of Electronic Media|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m6dYCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT77|date=8 January 2016|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-317-34792-7|pages=77–}}</ref><ref name="Kennett1985">{{cite book|author=Lee B. Kennett|title=For the Duration...: The United States Goes to War, Pearl Harbor-1942|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=81AIAAAAIAAJ|year=1985|publisher=Scribner|isbn=978-0-684-18239-1}}</ref>
== Specifications == The sets used a four-valve [[Superheterodyne receiver|superhet]] circuit with an audio output of 4 watts at 10% total [[harmonic distortion]]; they performed as well as many pre-war sets. The valve complement consisted of a [[Pentagrid converter#Hexode|triode-hexode]] [[frequency changer]], a [[variable mu|variable-μ]] RF [[pentode]] IF amplifier and a high slope output pentode. A "Westector" solid-state [[Metal_rectifier|copper oxide diode]] was used for [[demodulation]], which saved one valve and allowed use of an available type of pentode for the audio stage.<ref name="Miller2000"/> The [[HT (vacuum tube)|HT]] line was derived from a [[full wave rectifier]]. All valves were on International Octal sockets apart from the rectifier which was on a British 4-pin base. There were minor variations between set makers; for instance [[Philips]] used [[intermediate frequency|IF]] transformers with adjustable [[ferrite core]]s (so-called slug tuning) rather than the conventional trimmer capacitors.<ref name="Street2002" />
== Manufacturers == More than 40 manufacturers, such as [[Pye Ltd.]] and [[Marconiphone]], made Utility radios. The manufacturer of a particular set was not readily apparent to the general public, although each manufacturer stamped a code letter on the radio to identify themselves to dealers. UK makers often used different designations for the same valve (tube). Octal tubes might be of USA origin. All valves in the Utility radio used standard designations prefixed by BVA (British Valve Association). They were produced by valve makers such as [[Mullard]], [[Marconi-Osram Valve|MOV]], [[Cossor]], Mazda and Brimar. Dealers, knowing the maker of a set and which valve manufacturer that maker used, could easily deduce which pre-war types these were and make warranty claims on the manufacturer.<ref name="valve" />
==See also== *[[Antique radio]] *[[Volksempfänger]]

{{Infobox company | name = Zoomcar | logo = Zoomcar logo.png | type = [[Private company|Private]] | founder = Greg Moran, David Back | areas_served = [[Bangalore]], [[Goa]], [[Guwahati]], [[Delhi]], [[Gurgaon]], [[Noida]], [[Mumbai]], [[Navi Mumbai]], [[Kolkata]], [[Chennai]], [[Pune]], [[Hyderabad]], [[Telangana]], [[Chandigarh]], [[Jaipur]], [[Mysore]], [[Ahmedabad]], [[Vizag]], [[Coimbatore]], [[Mangalore]], [[Lucknow]], [[Bhubaneswar]], [[Kochi]], [[Varanasi]] and [[Udaipur]]<ref name="zoomcar">{{cite web|url=http://www.zoomcar.com|title=Self Drive Car Rental in India - Car Hire - Rent a car - Zoomcar|first=Zoomcar India Private|last=Ltd.|website=Zoomcar.com|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref> | industry = [[Car rental]] | services = "Self-drive" car rental | homepage = [http://www.zoomcar.com/ www.zoomcar.com] | foundation = {{start date and age|df=yes|2013|02}} | location = [[Bangalore]], [[India]] }}
'''Zoomcar''' is a self-drive [[car rental]] company headquartered in [[Bangalore]], [[India]]. The company was founded in 2013 by David Back and Greg Moran.<ref>{{cite web|title=14 startups to look forward to in 2014|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/slideshows/biz-entrepreneurship/14-startups-to-look-forward-to-in-2014/zoom/slideshow/27778004.cms|publisher=The Economic Times|accessdate=11 March 2014}}</ref> As of February 2017, the company operates in 27 cities across the country.
== History == American duo<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/article/industry/companies/india-calling-expat-preneurs/62910/|title=Business News, India Stock Market, Personal Finance, IPO, Financial News Headlines - The Financial Express|website=Financialexpress.com|accessdate=24 April 2018}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> David Back & Greg Moran, met while studying at the [[University of Pennsylvania]],<ref>{{cite web|title=High-tech entrepreneurs flock to India|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/high-tech-entrepreneurs-flock-india/|publisher=PBS NewsHour|accessdate=11 March 2014}}</ref> where both graduated in 2007. After graduating, Back studied at [[Harvard Law School]]<ref>{{cite web|title=President's challenge finalists selected|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2012/4/13/presidents-challenge-finalists-selected/|publisher=The Crimson}}</ref> and Moran worked on energy financing projects.<ref>{{cite web|title=Zoom Creates Self Drive Car Market Segment in India|url=http://vyapaari.in/zoom-creates-self-drive-car-market-segment-in-india/|publisher=vyapaari.in|accessdate=11 March 2014|author=Radhika Koppanur}}</ref> The pair also went on to business school with full scholarships, Moran at the [[University of Southern California]] and Back at the [[Judge Business School]] at [[Cambridge University]].
Back and Moran both dropped out of business school to move to India and pursue a venture in car rentals.<ref>{{cite web|title=Indian Drivers Attract Larry Summers|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2013/08/08/indian-drivers-attract-fed-hopeful-larry-summers/?mg=blogs-wsj&url=http%253A%252F%252Fblogs.wsj.com%252Findiarealtime%252F2013%252F08%252F08%252Findian-drivers-attract-fed-hopeful-larry-summers|publisher=Wall Street Journal India|accessdate=11 March 2014|author=Mark Bergen|date=8 August 2013}}</ref> In May 2015, Back resigned from the self-drive car rental company, and decided to move back to the US citing personal reasons.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.livemint.com/Companies/FbBqXR43mcegiaZEyzjkbI/Zoomcar-cofounder-David-Back-resigns.html|title=Zoomcar co-founder David Back resigns|last=Ambre|first=Ashna|date=2015-05-29|work=www.livemint.com/|access-date=2017-09-05}}</ref>
Zoom officially launched operations in Bangalore in February 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Zoom Inc. lets its customers enjoy the benefits of using a car without having to own it|url=http://entrepreneurindia.in/start-ups/zoom-inc-lets-its-customers-enjoy-the-benefits-of-using-a-car-without-having-to-own-it/18597/|publisher=Entrepreneur|accessdate=11 March 2014|author=Pranbihanga Borpuzari|date=23 March 2013}}</ref> Zoom started with $215,000 in capital and a fleet of seven cars.<ref>{{cite web|title=Attacking a $3 billion rent a car market|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/karstenstrauss/2013/04/01/attacking-a-3-billion-rent-a-car-market/|publisher=forbes.com|accessdate=11 March 2014}}</ref>
== Investors == Zoom initially raised capital from individual investors including Former US Treasury Secretary [[Lawrence Summers]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/Larry-Summers-fuels-Bangalore-car-hire-startup/articleshow/21735220.cms|title=Larry Summers fuels Bangalore car hire startup |newspaper=[[Times of India]]|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref> Chair of the UK Institute of Directors Lady [[Barbara Judge]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://techcircle.vccircle.com/2013/04/01/self-drive-car-rental-startup-zoom-raises-215k-in-angel-funding-targets-3b-rent-a-car-market/|title=Self-drive car rental startup Zoom raises $215K in angel funding; targets $3B rent-a-car market|date=1 April 2013|website=Techcircle.vccircle.com|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref> Vice-Dean of International Legal Studies at Harvard Law School [[William P. Alford]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.microsoftaccelerator.com/blog/entry/GlobalStartupStoriesZoomCar%7C1058# |title=Archived copy |access-date=24 August 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160920222235/https://www.microsoftaccelerator.com/blog/entry/GlobalStartupStoriesZoomCar%7C1058# |archive-date=20 September 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Wharton Statistics Chair Edward George,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.techinasia.com/ola-backer-sequoia-funds-zoomcars-hyperlocal-selfdrive-car-rental-disruptor-india|title=Tech in Asia - Connecting Asia's startup ecosystem|website=Techinasia.com|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref> and the former Director of the Cambridge Centre for Entrepreneurial Studies Shai Vyakarnam.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://qz.com/458266/how-two-americans-zoomed-into-indias-self-driven-car-rental-market/|title=How two Americans zoomed into India’s car rental market — Quartz|first=Itika Sharma|last=Punit|website=qz.com|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref> Back met Summers at [[Harvard University]], where Back was a teaching assistant to Summers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Indian Drivers Attract Larry Summers|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2013/08/08/indian-drivers-attract-fed-hopeful-larry-summers/?mg=blogs-wsj&url=http%253A%252F%252Fblogs.wsj.com%252Findiarealtime%252F2013%252F08%252F08%252Findian-drivers-attract-fed-hopeful-larry-summers|publisher=Wall Street Journal India|author=Mark Bergen|date=8 August 2013}}</ref>
Zoomcar's institutional investors include: [[Ford Motor Company]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/08/24/ford-leads-24m-investment-in-india-based-vehicle-rental-company-zoomcar/|title=Ford leads $24M investment in India-based vehicle rental company Zoomcar – TechCrunch|website=techcrunch.com|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref> [[Sequoia Capital]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2014-10-31/news/55631379_1_zoomcar-basset-investment-group-empire-angels# |title=Archived copy |access-date=24 August 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160916105054/http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2014-10-31/news/55631379_1_zoomcar-basset-investment-group-empire-angels# |archive-date=16 September 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Nokia Growth Partners]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nokiagrowthpartners.com/news/press-releases-media/ngp-invests-in-zoomcar/|title=News|date=26 August 2017|website=Nokiagrowrthpartners.com|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref> FundersClub,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fundersclub.com/companies/zoom/|title=FundersClub|website=fundersclub.com|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref> Basset Investment Group,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pehub.com/2013/10/empire-angels-leads-round-indian-car-rental-startup-zoomcar/|title=Empire Angels leads round for Indian car rental startup Zoomcar - PE Hub|date=3 October 2013|website=Pehub.com|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref> Athene Capital,<ref name="crunchbase_zoomcar-india">{{cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/zoomcar-india|title=ZoomCar - At [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]]'s investor day presentation in September 2016, CEO [[Mark Fields (businessman)|Mark Fields]] described difficulties with Ford's prior strategy in India, but commented "Our new mobility business could be a factor that plays in there. That's why you saw us about a month ago take an equity position in Zoomcar, which is the largest car sharing service in India."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fool.com/investing/2016/10/16/why-fords-ceo-is-having-second-thoughts-about-indi.aspx|title=Why Ford's CEO Is Having Second Thoughts About India|first=John|last=Rosevear|website=Fool.com|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref>
== Competition == Zoomcar faces competition from [[Drivezy (formerly JustRide)|Drivezy]], [[MylesCar]]s (backed by [[Carzonrent]]) and other similar car rental companies.
== Partnerships == Zoom partners with the auto manufacturers like [[Ford]] & [[Mahindra & Mahindra|Mahindra]] which allowed them to become the first car rental company in India to offer an electric vehicle (the Mahindra REVA E2O by Mahindra) and the Ford EcoSport "urban SUV by Ford" in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.at.ford.com/news/cn/Pages/Zoom%20Chooses%20Ford%20to%20Pioneer%20Innovative%20Car%20Rental%20Service%20in%20India.aspx|title=Zoom Chooses Ford to Pioneer Innovative Car Rental Service in India|date=24 April 2013|publisher=@Fordonline|accessdate=11 March 2014}}</ref> Zoom also works with locally established real estate developers, universities, hotels, and corporate IT parks to secure parking for its vehicles and offer pick-up points to its members.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bangalore.tie.org/article/8/featured-member-greg-moran|title=Featured Member : Greg Moran|publisher=TIE Bangalore Chapter}}</ref>
In November 2013, Zoom, [[Uber (company)|Uber]] (a cab booking mobile app provider) and the Ashoka Foundation came together and launched a month-long campaign in Bangalore called RideSmartBLR to encourage car-rental and discourage drunk driving for its health, economical and environmental benefits.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/tech/enterprise-it/services-apps/ZoomCar-Uber-launch-smart-riding-campaign-in-Bangalore/articleshow/26125804.cms|title=ZoomCar, Uber launch smart riding campaign in Bangalore|author=Shilpa Phadnis|date=21 November 2013|publisher=The Times Of India|accessdate=11 March 2014}}</ref>
Zoom was a member of [[Microsoft]]'s Accelerator Plus program in Bangalore in Spring 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/02/11/microsoft-accelerator-launches-new-program-for-late-stage-startups-in-india/|title=Microsoft Accelerator Launches New Program For Late Stage Startups In India}}</ref> This program is designed to provide more tailored assistance to later-stage start-ups as they scale their business and raise capital.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2014-02-11/news/47235579_1_startups-boutline-batch|title=16 tech startups selected for Microsoft Ventures Accelerator Program's latest batch|author=Economictimes.com|date=11 February 2014|publisher=The Economic Times|accessdate=11 March 2014}}</ref>
== Opposition == In July 2015, Zoomcar issued caution information to its customers following opposition from the [[Ladakh]] taxi union. Following an incident in which a convoy of 15 cars rented from the company was reportedly attacked by members of the union with stones and iron rods, Zoomcar issued a cautionary mail to customers traveling to Khardung La and Nubra valley.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Updated: Zoomcar & Myles advise caution after Ladakh taxi union revolts against self-drive rental cars|url = http://www.medianama.com/2015/07/223-zoomcar-ladakh-taxi-union/|website = MediaNama|accessdate = 2015-12-30}}</ref> The following week Zoom issued an update stating that the situation had aggravated and the company urged extreme caution to customers traveling to the region.<ref>{{Cite web|title = "The situation has aggravated"; Zoomcar advises extreme caution as taxi unions damage cars in Ladakh|url = http://www.medianama.com/2015/07/223-zoomcar-ladakh-taxi-union-cars/|website = MediaNama|accessdate = 2015-12-30}}</ref> The taxi unions of [[Gulmarg]] and Ladakh continue to resist entry of non-local commercial cars in the region.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Self drive rental service cos offer a string of benefits|url = http://www.businesstoday.in/magazine/features/self-drive-rental-service-companies-like-revv-zoomcar-myles-offers-a-string-of-benefits/story/226510.html|website = www.businesstoday.in|accessdate = 2015-12-30}}</ref>
== Controversy == In December 2015, the [[Advertising Standards Council of India]] [[Advertising Standards Council of India|(ASCI)]] banned 54 controversial Indian ads which included a video advertisement by Zoomcar.<ref>{{Cite web|title = ASCI bans 54 ads, including HUL, Godrej, Marico, Airtel 4G, Flipkart, Bennett Coleman & Co, HT Media, Shoppers Stop, HDFC Bank, Max Bupa, in September - Moneylife|url = http://www.moneylife.in/article/asci-bans-54-ads-including-hul-godrej-marico-airtel-4g-flipkart-bennett-coleman-co-ht-media-shoppers-stop-hdfc-bank-max-bupa-in-september/44495.html|website = www.moneylife.in|accessdate = 2015-12-21}}</ref> The ad was found to be in violation of India's [[Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961]] by the council, following which the advertisement was pulled off by the company.
